ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

COMPENSATION FOR MASSACRES
BY JAPANESE ARMY
IN SINGAPORE


    1. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Prime Minister if he will make a statement on his recent discussions with the Japanese Prime Minister on the question of compensation for the massacres by the Japanese army in Singapore in the last war.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, on the 25th of May, I paid a courtesy call on the Prime Minister of Japan and in the course of our conversation, he referred to the unfortunate incidents which took place during the war in Singapore in which our civilians were massacred by the Japanese army. He expressed his sincere regret for what had happened. I told him that there were strong feelings on the subject and that it was a very emotional issue. I told him also that the Japanese Government and people will have to make atonement to the people of Singapore. My conversation was an informal one because foreign affairs as distinct from trade relations are the responsibility of the United Kingdom Government, and as I have stated in answer to another question by the Member for Pasir Panjang, the question of war reparation including compensation for atrocities and war damage was the responsibility of the United Kingdom Government which in 1951 signed a treaty of peace with Japan.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, morally, we should get some sort of compensation. From

Column: 286

the reply given by the Prime Minister, we can see that the Japanese Government is very obstinate in this matter. So is the Government prepared to take further steps regarding this matter?

    The Prime Minister: I am sorry that the Member for Pasir Panjang did not listen to my reply, or perhaps he did not listen very carefully to the translation of my reply.

    To be fair to the Japanese, I did not find the Prime Minister's attitude to me "obstinate" - I do not know how the word was translated. I did not find him either obstinate or obdurate. He expressed his sincere regrets, and I indicated to him that beyond the expression of sincere regrets there should be an act of atonement to the people of Singapore. I know certain elements would like to see our trade relations with non-Communist and anti-Communist countries disrupted: I see no reason at the moment for embarking on any such action which the Member for Pasir Panjang has suggested.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister said that he had an informal conversation with the Prime Minister of Japan. He also told this House that the question of compensation, according to the Constitution of Singapore, is in the hands of the United Kingdom Government. But from what I know, the Government has brought up this matter of compensation with the United Kingdom Government. So can the Prime Minister tell this House: What is the present position of negotiations between the United Kingdom Government and Japan? When can a report be made on this matter to this House?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, if the Member for Choa Chu Kang will recollect, I indicated that we had written to the United Kingdom Commission who have communicated with their Government and they wanted evidence to show whether the bones found referred to massacres which were already known at the time of the war crimes and before the Treaty of San Francisco or whether they were new massacres in the sense

Column : 287

that they were unknown at the time of the war crimes and the Treaty of San Francisco.

    I have been in correspondence with the persons who are interested in these matters and who wish to exhume the bones and they have gone round to get the evidence of survivors. The evidence is being collated, although, as far as we can make out at the present moment, there is no clear evidence of any one of the massacres being unknown to the authorities either at the time of the Treaty of San Francisco or at the time of the war crimes. But the matter is still under investigation.

    Mr David Marshall: Will the Prime Minister indicate what was the reaction of the Prime Minister of Japan to his suggestion of material atonement!

    The Prime Minister: I think the Member for Anson, who spent some time, I believe living amongst the Japanese - albeit unwillingly - understands that the Japanese people are extremely polite on formal occasions. I can only say that I found him most receptive to everything that I said in the usual Japanese civilian way. [Interruption] I found in the typical Japanese, politeness of the host and not of the conqueror. I found him extremely courteous and listening attentively to my points, and he indicated that he would pass his views for close examination by his Foreign Minister and, in due course of time, I have no doubt there will be an official reaction.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Can the Prime Minister inform the House what action the Government intends to take if the Japanese Government ignores the request of the people for compensation?

    Mr Speaker: It is a hypothetical question.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, from a statement given by the Japanese, it was stated that this matter was settled by the Treaty of San Francisco. So from this, we can see that the request of Singapore

Column : 288

has not been met and that no compensation has been made towards the victims' families. What steps are the Government going to take!

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I would be delighted when the time comes to listen to any suggestion of martial activities as have been suggested by Members opposite. Yesterday I heard protestations of great love for peace and peace-loving methods and I am quite sure that when the time comes for them to play a different role, they will not be altogether barren of ideas of aggressive action. We are open to - as it is the duty of any democratic government - all suggestions from all quarters which we think would be to the benefit of the people of Singapore, and if the Member for Pasir Panjang lacks sufficient "martial" qualities, we are even prepared to attach him to the Second Infantry Battalion for training.

    Mr Speaker: Question No. 2, Mr Tee Kim Leng.

EXHUMATION OF MASS GRAVES
OF JAPANESE MASSACRE
VICTIMS


    2. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Prime Minister if he will state the reasons for not yet approving the application of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce to exhume the mass graves of victims of the massacres in the last war by the Japanese army.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the applications of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce to exhume the remains of victims of massacres by the Japanese in the last war were generally approved on the 6th of June. However, as I explained to the Chairman and representatives of the Chamber who saw me yesterday, there were certain technical matters which they will have to clear before the licence can be issued.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir, the Prime Minister says that because of some technical matter, the licence is now being held up for the time being. Can the Prime Minister tell this House what the technical matters are?

Column : 289



    The Prime Minister: I have said that there were certain technical matters. I have informed the Chamber of Commerce of them. They are having a meeting and they will be communicating with my Secretary and I do not think it is of any importance to this Assembly a: this stage to delve into these technical details. lt will not help matters.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Prime Minister tell this House when the licence will be granted?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, from time to time, I try my best to be a prophet and in this particular case all I can say is that I see no difficulty so long as the parties concerned can reach agreement on certain technical matters which have to be agreed to.

DEMOLITION OF UNAUTHORISED
STRUCTURES ON GOVERNMENT LAND


    3. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Prime Minister how many unauthorised structures on Government land have been demolished by the Land Office since June, 1959, and how many are due to be demolished.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, a total of 615 unauthorised structures were detected on State lands and demolished from June 1959 to 27th June, 1962. One un authorised shed is due for demolition next month. Demolition action is taken as and when unauthorised structures are detected. It is therefore not possible to predict when further unauthorised structures will be detected.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Can the Prime Minister take a sympathetic view of the fact that the farmers put up unauthorised houses because they are ignorant of the law? Can the Prime Minister issue them with temporary licences?

    The Prime Minister: I will quite willingly oblige everybody and forgive everybody, and in the case of the Member for Pasir Panjang, if there are

Column: 290

any vacant lands for schools, hospitals, clinics and community centres which are due for building but which unfortunately have buildings occupied by farmers in their ignorance of the law as to State land, and if he gets me a mass petition from the people in the neighbourhood saying that they would forego willingly the schools, hospitals, clinics and community centres in order that the farmers should not have to bear the consequences of their ignorance of going on to other people's land and building on it, then I will give serious consideration to this petition and to each specific case.

    I am quite sure the Member for Pasir Panjang knows that when he was in the People's Action Party he participated in an important series of conferences in which we decided that there should be a once and for all amnesty to everybody an terms an a clear warning to everybody else that any structure that went up would be smacked down the moment it was detected. I have no doubt that all his other pledges are of little value to him now.

    I say that if he, as the Member for Pasir Panjang, could convince me that the people of Pasir Panjang are quite happy to have their vacant lands, which have been left vacant for certain specified purposes, unlawfully occupied in this way and the public utilities and amenities frustrated, the Land Office and the Planning Department will give serious consideration to these petitions.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister says that I agreed to the demolition of huts. This is rather confusing the issue. I remember that when I was in the P.A.P. no such decision was arrived at any meeting. At that time, I suggested that unauthorised huts which were at least five years' old should be given temporary occupation licences.

    The Prime Minister: There were minutes kept of our meetings at which the Member for Pasir Panjang was present. A series of decisions were made as to old unauthorised structures on

Column : 291

State land and the position was regularised. Speaking now from memory, they were as follows: they were all to be given T.O.Ls: they were all to be let in accordance with the size of the building. Half the rent was to be set aside for refund to the occupant when he was asked to vacate and when building was to commence. All those provisions have been implemented, and all unlawful structures before June 1959 have been regularised. After that date, the position was made clear to everybody, by debates in this Assembly, in the newspapers and by land bailiffs informing all and sundry, not least of all the contractors, that any unlawful structure put up on any State land will be demolished on detection. And all the while that he was a Member of the Government, that policy had been expeditiously executed as I indicated - 615 houses had been demolished, of which some 470 were demolished at the time the Member for Pasir Panjang was supporting the Government.

TRANSFERRING OUT OF
TEACHERS WHO ARE
RELATED TO EACH OTHER
(Method adopted and Numbers)


    4. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Minister for Education to state (a) the method adopted in transferring out from a school, teachers therein who are related to each other; (b) how many such teachers have been transferred this year; and (c) how many have not been transferred.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, before I answer the question proper, may I be permitted to explain as follows? On the 24th August, 1959, a circular was issued to all school principals requiring them to declare a list of staff employed in each school of those who happen to be close relatives, defined as: - spouses, parents, brothers, sisters, or children. The purpose of the circular was to ensure fair and proper running of schools by breaking up teams of close relatives working in the same school, as far as possible.

Column: 292



    In reply to the first part of the question as to the method adopted in transferring out teachers who are closely related in accordance with the circular: in the case of Government schools, such teachers are generally posted to different schools by the Ministry itself. In the case of Government aided schools, the transfers are usually arranged mutually between teachers and principals of schools concerned, subject to approval by the Ministry.

    In reply to the second part of the question: as most transfers of this nature were effected during the two years 1960 and 1961, there were only four transfers for this year.

    To the last part of the question, from available records. 36 teachers affected by the circular have not been transferred with the knowledge and approval of the Ministry for a variety of reasons. The status quo is, however, only permitted subject to there being no complaints against these teachers. Otherwise one of the affected parties would have to be transferred out or be required to leave the service of the school altogether.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Education said that there were four transfers this year. Could he tell us whether every one of these four teachers is still teaching at the moment, or is he now unemployed?

    Mr Speaker: Has the Minister the question? It seems to be a different question.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: The four teachers who have been transferred have been put to other schools.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir,I know of a case in which a transferred teacher seems to have been dismissed. He is not teaching any longer.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have said in the past that Question Time is not the time merely to give information. A case like that could, easily have been brought to the notice of the Minister

Column : 293

or stated specifically in the Question, so that the Minister will be able to answer it. A general question followed by particularisation is not quite the proper course to take.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I would like to ask a question concerning those teachers who have not been transferred out. Can the Minister acquaint the House with the reasons for not transferring them out?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I have stated, Sir that those who have not been transferred have been allowed to stay in the schools concerned for special reasons and if there were no complaints against them. In certain cases like island schools, husbands and wives were permitted to stay together because certain teachers were not prepared to serve in island schools. In other cases, it was because it is difficult to replace such teachers if they are specialist teachers in Upper Secondary schools, or for health reasons and so forth where it was felt justified to permit such teachers to remain, subject to no complaints being received that the teachers concerned, being relatives, are ganging up seeking a favoured position in schools, and so forth.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Has the Minister concerned paid attention to the fact that some teachers who were supposed to have been transferred had, in fact, been dismissed?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, in my reply I mentioned that in the case of teachers who have not been transferred with our knowledge and approval, there were conditions attached to them, which were that 'there should be no complaints lodged against these teachers in the schools. Should there be complaints and if after investigation, they were found to be true, then one of the affected parties would have to be transferred out or leave the service of the school.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has made mention of teachers in island schools.

Column : 294

I would like to find out whether the Minister has noticed that apart from these island school teachers there has been a case where a couple have not been transferred, but in another case where the teachers are brothers, they have been transferred out. If the Minister wants the name pf the school concerned, I can give it to him.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think I should prevent all these what are technically called "fishing" questions. If the Member has a particular complaint, he can either complain direct to the Minister, or put it down in a question and particularise. I cannot allow fishing questions like that.

CHINESE SECONDARY IV
GRADUATES
IN GOVERNMENT SCHOOLS


    5. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Minister for Education how many Chinese Secondary Four graduates are teaching in Government and Government aided schools, and the dates of their appointments.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 38 graduates with the Government Secondary IV Chinese certificates teaching in Government and Government aided Chinese schools. The breakdown figures and dates of appointments of these teachers are as follows:

    In Government schools, one was appointed on 8th February, 1962; 20 appointed on 12th February, 1962; and 8 appointed on 8th March, 1962, making a total of 29.

    In Government aided schools, 2 were appointed on 2nd January, 1962, one an 10th January, 1962 and 6 on 24th April, 1962, making a total of 9.

    It should be added, however, that more than 80 per cent of those who have passed the internal School Secondary IV examination in Chinese Secondary schools are continuing their studies in Upper Secondary I classes this year.

LORONG TAI SENG-HOUSING
AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
OFFICE
(Procedure in letting out to P.A.P. Paya Lebar Branch)


    6. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Minister for National Development what was the procedure followed in letting out a new office of the Housing and Development Board at Lorong Tai Seng to the P.A.P. Paya Lebar Branch.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, I am indeed surprised that the Member for Pasir Panjang is still not aware that the normal procedure for applying for Housing Board office and shop accommodation is through public tenders invited through the medium of the Press and by notices pasted on the premises themselves. It is the practice of the Housing and Development Board to award tenancy of the premises in question to the highest tenderer.

    The vacant premises at No. 330-35 Lorong Tai Seng, together with other vacant Housing Board office and shop premises, were advertised for letting on 20th March, 1962. Prospective tenderers were invited to submit their offers to the Housing Board for these premises. There were three tenderers who offered $40/- per month, $50/- per month, and $55/- per month respectively for the premises. The highest tender of $55/- per month was from the Treasurer of the People's Action Party, and in accordance with normal practice this tenderer was awarded the tenancy of the premises in question.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, yesterday some Members of the Opposition cited precedents from other countries where only one question was put to the people. Precedents were quoted from both East and West. But I have explained that in most of the countries quoted by Members of the Opposition, there is only one nationality, one culture and one religion. We should not forget that the people of our country are different in race and religion. Therefore, the basis of democracy which should be practised here is to respect the views of all sections of the population. If we ignore this basic principle of democracy, then it will be a death-blow to democracy in our country.

    Mr Speaker, to return to the question which will be posed to the electorate; let us say that it will be on merger. All are unanimously agreed that merger must come. The question to be answered is what kind of merger. We must be aware that the Government have been elected by the people and that they have left their destiny in the hands of the Government. Therefore, the Government in im plementing the task entrusted to them must always bear in mind that the in terests of the people come first. The Government have on many occasions re iterated that we must respect the views of all sections of the people. I hope the Opposition will also respect the rights of all sections of the people. We should not think in terms of what we want. For instance, yesterday, the Member for Jalan Kayu quoted the example of buying an article in a shop and that if the article offered to us is unacceptable we go to the next shop. We can go from Sungei Road to Robinson, Sir, but there is a difference in the price. The prices of articles in Sungei Road vary very much from those in Robinson. The price of an article depends on its quality. So it is with merger. If we want a super mer ger, then we must be prepared for sacrifices. But instead of fighting for the rights which we are enjoying now, we are asking for other rights. As I said previously, our wives will remain our wives. But we should not be asking for other people's wives. If the Federation of

Column: 298

Malaya can be likened to a shop and if the products sold in that shop are not suitable, where shall we go? We do not want Singapore and the Federation of Malaya to be a second Palestine. We must admit that this referendum is on a national issue and not on a political issue. In facing this national issue, we must be realistic. We must respect one another's views and rights. We must not make this Referendum Bill an issue for winning the next election. We must be fully aware of this as we are the elected representatives of the people in whose hands the people have put heir destiny. Therefore, Mr Speaker, in facing this issue, we oppose the proposition that only one question is to be put to the elec torate. We must submit a number of reasonable questions because we are concerned with merger. There must be agreement on both sides and the view of the other side should be taken into consideration as well. If I take my child to a shop, he might want to buy expensive articles. But I must first find out whether I have enough money in my pocket before I can buy them for him. So, if what I have just said materialises, then Singapore and the Federation will be a second Palestine. There will be no peace between these two countries. 'Therefore, political leaders, in facing this problem, must be sober in the interests of national unity and peace for the country.

    Miss Fung Yin Ching (Stamford)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, let me say something on this disgusting National Referendum Bill. It does not look like a national Referendum Bill. It is something like a repressive Bill. It does not re ally reflect the views of the people. This Bill can only force the people to choose two unacceptable alternatives. The people in the whole of Singapore know that this Bill is a very undemocratic Bill. The Government have put on the cloak of democracy. But, as a matter of fact, they are selling the contents of democracy. Therefore, this Bill is a plot.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have reason to believe that this national Referendum Bill has been created by some of the leaders in the P.A.P. in order to trap the people.

Therefore, I hope that the Back-Benchers of the Government Party will come forward to uphold justice and the people's democratic rights.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Speaker, now let me come back to the clause. The clause which we have been discussing is one of the most important clauses. Mr Speaker, Sir, if the amendment proposed by the Opposition is not acceptable by the Government, then it only proves that the Party in power does not dare to face the people. It also proves that the P.A.P. Government has lost its own confidence in the White Paper merger proposals. Mr Speaker. Sir, regarding the questions why the leaders of the P.A.P. have to go back on their word, why they want to distort facts, why they dare not bring up their White Paper proposals for the people to decide, let us see whether the people want their proposals or not. Mr Speaker, this question has been debated in this House for a long time, because the Party in power itself knows that its own White Paper proposals are not in accordance with the views of the majority of the people. If the Government put forward these proposals they are sure to be rejected by the people. Therefore, the leaders of the Government shamelessly go back on their word. Mr Speaker, Sir, the Gov ernment leaders have decided to pose two questions to the people for their de cision. This is clear to everyone and we have spoken at great length on this. But originally the Government wanted to pose only one question, but now they have decided to pose two questions. The P.A.P. leaders are very clever people. They can think out all sorts of devices. What is the device? It is that they try to create confusion over the title of the Bill. The Government has altered a specific Bill for the specific question of merger to a general Bill. This Bill has been changed by the Government into a general Bill, so that the Party in power can pose one, two, three or four questions to the people. Mr Speaker, Sir, because the Government have changed the fundamental nature of this Bill, therefore they are trying to quote instances from other countries to justify their stand . This is meant only to confuse the vision of the

people. Mr Speaker, Sir, let me quote some examples to show you how the Government are trying to confuse the people's vision. This is a copy of the Sin Chew Jit Poh of 7th of June in the local field. A speech by the Political Secretary to the Prime Minister was published on this page in which he said:

    'Here the Government has decided to hold a national Referendum on the question of merger. However, we must be clear that this National Referendum Bill is not only meant for this merger issue; it is not only applicable to a referendum on the merger issue, but it is also intended to be applied for future referenda on other issues.'

And in discussing this Bill the question of merger was mentioned. This is be cause it is necessary to cite examples. It is not a central question.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we all know that this Bill was brought up because the Gov ernment wanted to carry out its White Paper merger proposals, but today the Government try to describe it as a general National Referendum Bill. The Government at the same time have inserted certain provisions into this Bill in order to distort it: that is to say, if there is only one question posed to the people, then it means a waste of public money. This is said by the Political Secretary to the Prime Minister. He is trying to distort the spirit of this Bill into something else. Now, let me quote him. This was on the 9th of this month. It was published in the local news, the Sin Chew Jit Poh. Mr Speaker, Sir, in this article he said about the Select Committee:

    'There is someone who mentioned two examples. One example is the question of Malay as the official language. Everybody agrees that this should be so. But when Malay is made the national language, evervbody agrees that it should be the official language. But there might be a divergency of views on when this should be implemented. Therefore, the Government should seek the views of the people. Therefore, the Government will have to ask the people whether it should be implemented in 5 years or 7 years or 10 years. The second example is a hypothetical example, and that is the control of toddy shops. This example shows that if only one question is posed and if the answer requires only 'yes' or 'no', it might become very restrictive. These two examples show that if the answer is a straightforward 'yes' or 'no', it will not effectively reflect the views of the people, If in the national Referendum we provide only one question, then the Government has to hold 3
